name: Faramea_fosteri
collectorTeam: R. Rojas, G. Ortiz & T. Carhuaricra
distribution: Peru (Western South America, Southern America);Mato Grosso (Brazil West-Central, Brazil, Southern America);Colombia (Western South America, Southern America);Ecuador (Western South America, Southern America);
locality: Peru. Pasco: prov. Oxapampa, distr. Palcazu, comunidad nativa Alto Lagarto, Reserva Comunal Yanesha, 500m
remarks: doi:10.3417/2019552 Named in honour of Dr. Robin B. Foster, an extraordinary tropical botanist who has led primary exploration of numerous regions of tropical America, helped develop the field of tropical plant ecology, and mentored numerous younger colleagues.

name: Faramea_neilliana
distribution: Acre (Brazil North, Brazil, Southern America);Bolivia (Western South America, Southern America);Colombia (Western South America, Southern America);Ecuador (Western South America, Southern America);Peru (Western South America, Southern America);
locality: Peru. San Martin: San Martin, caserio El Progreso, Tarapoto–Yurimaguas rd., 700m
remarks: doi:10.3417/2019552 The epithet honours Dr. David Neill, an extraordinary botanist who has studied the flora of Ecuador extensively and expertly for several decades; he and his collaborators have discovered and documented numerous new plant species in that region, including this one.

remarks: doi:10.1590/0001-3765202320211601 Etymology: the specific epithet honours Julio Antonio Lombardi, who collected the holotype.

remarks: doi:10.5852/ejt.2022.806.1713 Etymology: the epithet refers to the municipality of Itacambira, in the state of Minas Gerais..ʻItakangapyraʼ means ʻstone with a pointed headʼ and derives from the ancient Tupi, an extinct Tupi language that was spoken by the Tupi tribes that inhabited most of the Brazilian coast in the 16th century.
